I want Tribes and communities in New Mexico and across the nation to know that I won’t give up on helping to end this crisis.

If you or a loved one is a victim of domestic or sexual violence please call the #StrongHearts Native helpline https://strongheartshelpline.org/ (8/8)

And today, alongside my colleagues, I cosponsored the introduction of National Day of Awareness for Missing & Murdered Native Women & Girls – so we pause to remember the women and children that have been taken from us & commit to finding those who are still lost. (7/8)

CONFIRMED: Marc B. Nathanson to be US Ambassador to the Kingdom of Norway

By voice vote.

In 2021, @SecDebHaaland rolled out a Missing and Murdered Unit that focuses on fact-gathering, publicizing and solving MMIP cases, and Congress took action by passing VAWA, Savanna's Act, the Not Invisible Act and my Native Youth and Tribal Officer Protection Act. (6/8)

There is very little research done on Native homicides, trafficking, and kidnapping. Let alone documentation. American Indian and Alaska Native people are at a disproportionate risk of experiencing violence, murder, or going missing. (5/8)

More than 4 in 5 American Indian and Alaska Native women (84.3%) and men (79%) have experienced violence in their lifetimes. Yes – you read that correctly – more than 80% of Native people. 

These are epidemic numbers, but hardly ever talked about on the national level. (4/8)

Sometimes search parties work tirelessly for months, in some cases years, leaving families and Tribes without answers or their loved ones. These are not isolated incidences or random coincidences. (3/8)

For hundreds of years, Tribal and Indigenous people have been disappearing. Their families plead with local law enforcement to get involved or provide them updates on cases – often left to self-organize search parties and hotlines. (2/8)
I need to talk to you about a serious problem that has touched communities across the country. (1/8)
